content.question:
Which of these statements about an anti-skid system are correct or incorrect?
1. The "regulation of slip ratio" function of an anti-skid system ensures optimum braking performance
2. Careful brake application by the pilot in case of anti-skid failure can never achieve the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: Statement 1: The "regulation of slip ratio" function of an anti-skid system ensures optimum braking performance
Is correct, this is the function of the ant-skid system as it notices any indication of when a wheel starts skidding and will regulate braking pressure to ensure optimum braking performance
Statement 2: Careful brake application by the pilot in case of anti-skid failure can never achieve the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system
learning.explanation: Statement 1: The "regulation of slip ratio" function of an anti-skid system ensures optimum braking performance. Is correct, this is the function of the ant-skid system as it notices any indication of when a wheel starts skidding and will regulate braking pressure to ensure optimum braking performance. Statement 2: Careful brake application by the pilot in case of anti-skid failure can never achieve the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. Correct, a pilot will never reach the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. The anti-skid system senses when a brake starts to skid and will reduce braking pressure to avoid the wheels from skidding, a pilot won’t come close to the same performance.

content.question: Which of these statements about an auto-brake system during RTO (Rejected Take Off) is correct?

options.A: Manual braking is always the best stopping technique for a rejected take-off.
options.B: In the RTO mode maximum anti-skid braking is applied.
options.C: An auto-brake system disarms automatically when the aeroplane has come to a standstill after a RTO.
options.D: When the RTO mode is armed, the system will operate at any speed when the take-off is aborted.

key_points: Manual braking is always the best stopping technique for a rejected take-off
Incorrect, the auto-brakes will always decelerate at the most efficient way
In the RTO mode maximum anti-skid braking is applied
learning.explanation: Manual braking is always the best stopping technique for a rejected take-off. Incorrect, the auto-brakes will always decelerate at the most efficient way. In the RTO mode maximum anti-skid braking is applied. In all auto-brake modes anti-skid is used. An auto-brake system disarms automatically when the aeroplane has come to a standstill after a RTO The auto-brake will never deactivate without pilot action. When the RTO mode is armed, the system will operate at any speed when the take-off is aborted. Incorrect, the RTO mode will only activate above a certain speed (85kts) The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated.

content.question: To enhance brake life in relation to brake wear, it is recommended…

options.A: for steel brakes to use a single, firm brake application during taxi.
options.B: for carbon brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
options.C: for steel brakes to use a large number of small brake applications during taxi.
options.D: for both carbon and steel brakes to use differential braking to reduce brake temperatures.

key_points: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life
Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes
Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications
learning.explanation: Because the wear mechanisms are different between carbon and steel brakes, different taxi braking techniques are recommended for carbon brakes in order to maximize brake life. Steel brake wear is directly proportional to the kinetic energy absorbed by the brakes. Maximum steel brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a large number of small, light brake applications, allowing some time for brake cooling between applications. High airplane gross weights and high brake application speeds tend to reduce steel brake life because they require the brakes to absorb a large amount of kinetic energy. Carbon brake wear is primarily dependent on the total number of brake applications — one firm brake application causes less wear than several light applications. Maximum carbon brake life can be achieved during taxi by using a small number of long, moderately firm brake applications instead of numerous light brake applications. This can be achieved by allowing taxi speed to increase from below target speed to above target speed, then using a single firm brake application to reduce speed below the target and repeating if required, rather than maintaining a constant taxi speed using numerous brake applications. Carbon brake wear is much less sensitive to airplane weight and speed than steel brake wear.

Which of these statements about an auto-brake system are correct or incorrect?
1. Proper functioning of an auto-brake system requires proper functioning of the anti-skid system
2. In the RTO mode a maximum constant deceleration is applied

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: Statement 1: Proper functioning of an auto-brake system requires proper functioning of the anti-skid system
This is correct, if the anti-skid function is inoperative the auto-brake will not work
Statement 2: In the RTO mode a maximum constant deceleration is applied
learning.explanation: Statement 1: Proper functioning of an auto-brake system requires proper functioning of the anti-skid system. This is correct, if the anti-skid function is inoperative the auto-brake will not work. Statement 2: In the RTO mode a maximum constant deceleration is applied. This is incorrect, because when the runway has slippery spots, the anti-skid will decrease brake pressure to avoid slipping of the wheels. This will cause deceleration to decrease but it will make sure the brake distance is its minimum amount.

content.question:
Which of the following are features of the anti-skid system?
1. Prevents brake application on touchdown
2. Steadily increases brake pressure as the aircraft slows
3. Release brake pressure as the brakes approach maximum temperature
4. Release brake pressure on some wheels on a bogie to allow continued breaking on other wheels
5. Reduces the runway length requirement for take-off

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance. In addition to the main optimised braking function, anti-skid systems offer other functions including: The ASU prevents brake application before touchdown on landing. It will prevent any brake pressure even if brake pedals are pressed before touchdown to allow the stationary wheels to spin-up to speed on contact. Only after spin-up does the ASU allow brake preassure application. The ASU protects against the locking of any wheel during the braking process by avoiding excessive wheel-slip values. The ASU protects against the effects of hydroplanning.

content.question: The wear of a multi-disk brake system which is commonly found on a commercial airliner can be spotted...

options.A: By Measuring the amount that the retraction pin extends from the spring housing.
options.B: By evaluating the distance the brake pedals move before the pads come into contact with the brake disk.
options.C: By visually checking the wear of the pads.
options.D: By checking the temperature of the brake system after landing.

key_points: Many brake assemblies contain a built-in wear indicator pin
During each application of the brakes, disc material is worn away by frictional forces
A wear indicator/lining indicator in the form of a pin that protrudes out of the carrier assembly indicates the thickness of the stack of discs
learning.explanation: Many brake assemblies contain a built-in wear indicator pin. During each application of the brakes, disc material is worn away by frictional forces. A wear indicator/lining indicator in the form of a pin that protrudes out of the carrier assembly indicates the thickness of the stack of discs. Over hundreds of brake applications, material wears away and discs become thinner, requiring replacement following periodic maintenance intervals. Typically, the exposed pin length decreases as the linings wear, and a minimum length is used to indicate the linings must be replaced.

content.question: Consider an aircraft with hydraulically operated brakes and a pneumatically operated emergency braking system, which uses the normal hydraulic brake lines. The aircraft also has an anti-skid system to avoid loss of control and locked wheels during braking. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The anti-skid system will allow for a lower brake temperature when braking hard.
options.B: After using the emergency braking system, the brake pedals will feel softer underfoot.
options.C: Normal braking is available after using the emergency braking system, provided it is operational.
options.D: The emergency braking system will be able to stop in a shorter distance, compared to normal braking.

key_points: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action
This is, of course, a hydraulic system
Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft
learning.explanation: Brakes on a car are operated by the driver pushing on the brake pedal, which uses a piston to squeeze hydraulic fluid into the brake lines, which then applies a force on the brake pads, pressing the pads onto the spinning disks to create friction, which gives braking action. This is, of course, a hydraulic system. Hydraulic systems are an excellent way to transfer forces around a vehicle like a car or an aircraft. The main benefit of hydraulics is that the fluid is not compressible, so the force from the brake pedal piston is immediately (and completely) transferred onto the brake pads. This applies to an aircraft as well, as the only difference is that large aircraft brakes use multiple brake pads (stators) and brake disks (rotors), and the braking systems are usually supplemented by the high pressure hydraulic systems that run the rest of the aircraft's systems to gain higher forces than just the pilot's feet can produce. The emergency braking system that is mentioned in this question is to be used in the case of a loss of hydraulic pressure, and extra pressure can be gained by firing a single burst of high pressure gas into the brake lines, which then allow the brakes to be used (not nicely, but better than nothing). Because of the gas (most likely Nitrogen to reduce fire risk) now inside the hydraulic brake lines, the force applied to the pedals is not going to be completely applied to the brakes, as some of the pressure is absorbed by the compression of the gas in the lines. This makes the brakes feel "soft" or "spongy" underfoot, and not nearly as reactive or sensitive. After this is used, the brake lines will have to be bled again to remove the remaining air in the system, and replace it completely with hydraulic fluid. The gas canister will be replaced for emergency brake system use in the future. Mention of the anti-skid system is there to throw you off. Anti-skid improves braking by stopping the wheels from locking up, so actually increases brake temperature (or does not affect it, depending on the conditions).

Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.08: Describe the sequence for emergency gear extension: unlocking; operating; down-locking. All aircraft are different in their emergency gear extension, but on the whole, the concept is the same. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. Many system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. We are assuming that "activating the uplocks" in this sense refers to the mechanical unlocking process of the gear uplocks. This is usually a cable that is pulled from the flight deck by some means, which overcomes the spring tension on the uplock, releasing the gear (and/or gear doors) to extend by gravity. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure (not the selector valves, they are different) Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

options.B: The autobrakes will attempt to maintain a constant rate of deceleration.
options.C: The pilot will have to apply maximum manual braking.

key_points: Note: The feedback for this question is incomplete

Please let us know if you see it in the exam, any differences you can remember, and if the answer was the same (if available), thank you! AUTOBRAKE SYSTEM The autobrake system uses hydraulic system pressure to provide maximum braking in the event of a rejected take-off and automatic braking at preselected deceleration rates immediately after touchdown on landing
REJECTED TAKEOFF (RTO) The RTO mode can be selected (armed) only when on the ground

Please let us know if you see it in the exam, any differences you can remember, and if the answer was the same (if available), thank you! AUTOBRAKE SYSTEM The autobrake system uses hydraulic system pressure to provide maximum braking in the event of a rejected take-off and automatic braking at preselected deceleration rates immediately after touchdown on landing. REJECTED TAKEOFF (RTO) The RTO mode can be selected (armed) only when on the ground. The RTO mode will engage when a few conditions are met, such as being above 88kts and setting the thrust levers to idle (B737). The airbus A320 doesn't have a named RTO mode, but MAX is only ever used for RTOs and it engages when the ground spoilers deploy, which is at or above 72 kt and with thrust levers set to idle. They are all very similar systems, with small variations. The autobrake applies maximum braking and it can be disconnected at any time by the pilot, who can then apply brakes manually. It does not provide a constant rate of deceleration as the landing autobrake modes attempt to do. You could argue that it "applies the anti-skid maximum braking" as anti-skid would reduce the brake pressure if the traction is not good enough, but this is not mentioned and we would consider this a less correct answer, particularly after looking at the learning objectives and previous questions.

content.question: After landing, with the autobrake system set to a constant deceleration rate, the use of thrust reversers will...

options.A: decrease the brake pressure.
options.B: change the configuration of the ground spoilers.
options.C: increase the landing distance.
options.D: increase the brake pressure.

key_points: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately
The correct answer is the same
The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO)
learning.explanation: Note: This is quite similar to Q215119, but has a couple of small changes to the question and options, so we have added it separately. The correct answer is the same. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). Autobrakes have quite a simple logic system, depending on their mode of operation, they use the wheel brakes to slow down the aircraft at a pre-determined, constant rate of deceleration (you can think of it as a constant G-force, or a constant amount of knots lost per second). This is independent on the weight of the aircraft, and the only thing that can usually hamper this is any lack of traction on the runway (wet, ice, etc.). This standard deceleration rate means that the use of any other deceleration methods will simply take some of the energy away from the brakes, making their job easier. The autobrake system does not care how easy the braking is though, it is very set on gaining a constant rate of deceleration, so applying reverse thrust would not change the rate of deceleration, it would just make the brakes cooler at the end of the landing, as they have worked less hard. The way the autobrake system controls this is by modulating the brake pressure, this is the hydraulic pressure which pushes the brake stators into the rotors. To make the brakes work less hard, the autobrake system reduces the brake pressure.

A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-reversable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks and hydraulic locks through a mechanical linkage. These can be used to allow the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means, these down-locks work automatically and mechanically once the gear reaches the down position. Another consideration is that of the hydraulic system, as usually landing gear is held up during flight by a combination of the mechanical up-locks and the hydraulic pressure being sealed off within the actuators. To release the gear for free fall, the correct sequence of actions would usually be: Release the hydraulic cut-off valve holding the hydraulic pressure. Release the locks holding the undercarriage doors (if fitted). Release the mechanical uplocks holding the gear up. One or all of these items may have to be performed manually, using mechanical pulley systems. Compressed gas can also be fired for the purposes of releasing mechanical up-locks.

Automatic Braking (Autobrake) systems offer two modes of operation: Landing Mode Rejected Take-Off (RTO) Mode In Landing Mode (1, 2, 3, MAX), calibrated pressure is automatically applied to the brakes upon touchdown, regardless of pilot input. This system adjusts brake pressure to counteract aircraft drag, thrust reversers, and spoilers, maintaining the chosen deceleration level for modes 1, 2 and 3 and maximum braking for MAX. The Rejected Take-Off (RTO) setting instructs the autobrake system to apply full pressure to the wheel brakes, bringing the aircraft to a stop. Activation of RTO mode occurs when a rejected takeoff is initiated by the pilot at a groundspeed exceeding 88 knots. content.question: On landing gear, most stress is carried by a torsion link...

options.A: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.B: on the outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.
options.C: on the inner cylinder of the main oleo leg during a large radius turn.
options.D: between the inner and outer cylinder of the main oleo leg during a small radius turn.

key_points: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load
Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around
With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction
learning.explanation: The torsion link on landing gear is the component shown in the annex above which stops the gear twisting round under load. Without the torsion link, there would be no directional control over the landing gear, and it would be free to spin around. With the wheel connected to the inner cylinder of the oleo, and the aircraft connected to the outer cylinder, there would be no mechanical connection between the two, only a little friction. The torsion link provides that mechanical connection between the inner and the outer cylinder (the wheel and the aircraft) in only one direction, preventing sideways movement, whilst still allowing shock absorption by the oleo in the up and down direction, as it moves in and out due to its "scissor link" design. The torsion link does carry lots of stress, therefore, when the aircraft wants to turn and the wheel does not. For example, a main wheel (without steering capability) going round a tight corner where the aircraft wants to twist sideways but the wheel does not. Even more than this, a bogie beam with multiple attached landing gear going round a similarly small corner, would have huge amounts of stress through the torsion link.

learning.explanation: Anti-skid is the system that stops our wheels "locking up" in wet or slippery runway conditions, as that would only damage our tyres, remove our controllability and provide a reduced braking performance. Instead, we want our tyres to be going just slightly slower than our groundspeed, to provide the greatest braking efficiency, especially in low traction conditions, and this is what anti-skid does. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. content.question: Which of these statements about an auto-brake system is correct?

options.A: When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
options.B: On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance
options.C: The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same
options.D: When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm

key_points: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature
” INCORRECT

It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers
learning.explanation: “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When using manual braking during taxiing, the auto-brake system will disarm” INCORRECT. During taxi we only ever use manual braking, therefore, the reference to the use of autobrake during taxi does not make sense. “On most aeroplanes the auto-brake system provides the capability to select a fixed landing distance” INCORRECT. Only a few aircraft do that, I believe the A350 and A380 – where you can actually go into the computer and say “this is the runway we are landing on, and I actually want to vacate at this specific exit” because it has the runway in the database and all the different taxiways off the runway and, therefore, you can use the autobrake and select to vacate at a certain exit and it will make sure you have the right speed to vacate => but that is not the majority of the aeroplanes. Ultimately, it is not very practical because there are a lot of different factors. On most aircrafts, it just provides a fixed deceleration rate but not a fixed landing distance (seen it is subjected to wind as well). You can never say it will precisely take this xxx amount of distance. Hopefully, this makes sense. “The achievable deceleration levels of full manual braking and the auto-brake RTO mode are the same” CORRECT. So if you press on the pedals as hard as you possibly can, it’s going to give you a maximum deceleration rate and it will also ensure that the wheels don’t lock up – which is exactly the same as autobrake max/RTO. If you look at the pushbutton, it says MAX - maximum amount of braking so it is the same as if you push on the pedals as hard as you can. (Don’t forget that you’ve got antiskid which works in conjunction with autobrake as well) => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. But the thing with the autobrake is that, as soon as the pilot decides to reject the take off and closes the thrust levers, then the maximum braking pressure gets applied immediately. Whereas, if you were to take off without autobrake, and then decided to abort the take-off, you’d first think about “right, I have got to close the thrust levers” and then you’ve got to think to press on the brake pedals => so, there’s obviously an element of delay in that. And that is why the stopping distance in the event of a manual rejected take off would be greater, even though the brake pressure on the brakes, would be exactly the same under both circumstances. content.question: What happens if the grooves or tread of an aircraft tyre are worn?

options.A: The tyre can be used on the nose wheel only.
options.B: The tyre can never be repaired or retreaded.
options.C: The tyre can be retreaded several times.
options.D: The tyre can be retreaded once.

key_points: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread)
This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away
All the tire needs is a new tread
learning.explanation: The tread of an airplane tire will wear out long before its casing (everything other than the tread). This means that the tire casing remains entirely capable of safely holding the inflation pressure to support the load of the airplane long after the tread has worn away. All the tire needs is a new tread. Airplane tires can be expensive: there is no logical reason to scrap a tire for an aircraft when it can be safely and economically reconditioned with a new tread. This is why retreading has been standard practice in the aviation industry for decades. The maximum retread level for the part number is set only after extensive testing and analysis. Some airplane tyres can be safely retreaded up to seven or more times, but there is always a limit and the limit is always set with an abundance of caution. The retread process is easy to understand. A worn tyre is removed from an aircraft. It is sent back to a retreading firm, often a manufacturer of airplane tires. When the firm receives a tire for retreading it is carefully inspected to ensure that it is safe and economical to retread. The tyre is scrapped if technicians consider there to be doubt about its airworthiness.

All modern aircraft now use disc brakes as their means of slowing down or stopping. Steel and carbon emerge as the principal constituents used in the fabrication of these brake components, each offering unique benefits. Conventional brake discs are typically fashioned from steel, boasting durability, cost-efficiency, and consistent braking performance. Carbon is also harnessed in brake assembly due to its superior heat absorption and dissipation characteristics. Carbon brakes exhibit notably lighter weight compared to their steel counterparts. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft
A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall
learning.explanation: The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main power system fails. There are numerous ways in which this is done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A means of extending the landing gear and locking it in the down position in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. Such system allows the landing gear to essentially "free fall" under the influence of gravity from their retracted and up-locked position to an extended and down-locked position. This is usually a one-time non-revisable operation. In order to activate this system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through a mechanical linkage. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released (unlocked), either either by mechanic or electronic means. This allows the gears to free-fall under their own weight. The weight of the gears will push the doors open. The gears will remain in the down and locked position by mechanical means.

key_points: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane
The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems
These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction
learning.explanation: EMERGENCY GEAR EXTENSION When you establish that the gear has failed to extend, you should be ready to use whatever type of emergency landing gear system is available in the aeroplane. The most common kinds you will see are the hand crank, hand pump hydraulic, free fall and pressurized nitrogen bottle systems. These systems are designed for emergency gear extension - not retraction. Failure of gear to retract is not an emergency unless it retracts partially and cannot be extended again In the pressurized nitrogen bottle system, the emergency gear extension system is activated by pulling the red EMER GEAR CONTROL handle, allowing a one shot extension of the landing gear. Once activated, nitrogen pressure from the emergency air bottle is released through a shuttle valve to the extend side of the landing gear actuators, extending the gear towards the down and locked position. Once the gear has fully extended, the down locks inside the actuators will engage and the down and locked micro switches will be energised causing the three green down and locked lights to illuminate. Once the emergency gear extension procedure has been used, subsequent retraction of the landing gear cannot be achieved. Ground servicing of the system is required prior to normal use of the system.

content.question:
Which of the following statements about an anti-skid system are correct/incorrect?
(1) The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance
(2) If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid

options.A: (1) is incorrect; (2) is incorrect.
options.B: (1) is correct; (2) is incorrect.
options.C: (1) is correct; (2) is correct.
options.D: (1) is incorrect; (2) is correct.

key_points: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems
It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies
A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost
learning.explanation: ANTI-SKID SYSTEM Large aircraft with power brakes require anti-skid systems. It is not possible to immediately ascertain in the flight deck when a wheel stops rotating and begins to skid, especially in aircrafts with multiple-wheel main landing gear assemblies. A skid not corrected can quickly lead to a tire blowout, possible damage to the aircraft, and control of the aircraft may be lost. One of the important issues to realize is that the anti-skid system greatly increases the effectiveness of braking. In very simplified terms, the anti-skid system provides the greatest possible brake pressure while not allowing the wheels to lock due to an excessive brake pressure being applied. Without the anti-skid system (manual braking) the braking effectiveness is reduced. "The anti-skid computer compares wheel speed to aeroplane reference speed to provide a slip ratio for maximum braking performance." Correct. These systems use a computer that, during ground movement when braking, which constantly compares the measured values of individual wheels (actual rotational speed) with the desired optimum parameters, providing a slip ratio for maximum braking performance. "If a pilot is careful when braking manually, he/she will be able to achieve the same braking efficiency as if braking with anti-skid." Incorrect. A pilot will never reach the same performance as a properly functioning anti-skid system. The anti-skid system senses when a brake starts to skid and will reduce braking pressure to avoid the wheels from skidding, a pilot won’t come close to the same performance.

So, when you select “low” autobrake mode in flight, on the landing roll out – it varies the brake pressure to achieve that deceleration rate always. If it is a contaminated runway and it can’t achieve that rate, fundamentally, it will just achieve what it can achieve. “When a low auto-brake setting is used during landing use of reverse will not influence the brake temperature.” INCORRECT. It obviously will, the autobrake varies the brake pressure to achieve a constant deceleration, so therefore, if you’re using thrust reversers, some of that energy (to dissipate speed to achieve a certain deceleration rate) is being supplied by the use of thrust reversers – therefore, they reduce the amount of brake pressure which has to be applied on the brakes => brake temperature will reduce as a result of using reversers. “When the auto-brake system is inoperative, in general take-off is not allowed, because maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in the RTO mode.” INCORRECT. I would say that this is a bit type specific. However, saying that the maximum manual braking does not achieve the same deceleration as the auto-brake system in RTO IS NOT CORRECT. => Fundamentally, if autobrake is in rejected take off RTO mode and you reject the take off => then the braking will be maximum possible braking, which is exactly the same as if you press on the pedals maximum. content.question: Landing gear torsion links are used to…

options.A: control the rate of oleo strut recoil.
options.B: prevent rotation of the landing gear piston in the oleo strut.
options.C: absorb the lateral stresses to which the gear is subjected.
options.D: prevent extension of the oleo strut when the gear is retracted.

key_points: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder
So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link
When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The function of a torsion link, or torque link, is to avoid movement of the inner cylinder within the outer cylinder. So when the aircraft is moving forward without turning there will not be much force on the torsion link. When the aircraft touches down with a strong cross-wind there might be some forces on the torque link, but most of the movement will be forward in line with the direction of the aircraft. When the aircraft is turning on the ground and especially turns with a small radius, the wheels will want to move forward whilst the aircraft is turning, this will cause a lot of load on the torsion link.

content.question: Light aircraft and helicopters may equipped with a “blowdown” emergency gear extension system for use in case of hydraulic failure. Which gasses are used for this purpose, and how are the gasses sent to the actuators?

options.A: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.
options.B: Helium or nitrogen, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.C: Nitrogen or compressed air, which is routed to parallel actuators on the landing gear.
options.D: Helium or carbon dioxide, which is routed through a manually operated shuttle valve.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.04.01.02.09: Describe some methods for emergency gear extension including: gravity/free fall; air or nitrogen pressure; manually/mechanically. The emergency extension system lowers the landing gear if the main hydraulic system fails. There are numerous ways in which this can be done depending on the size and complexity of the aircraft. A very common way of extending the landing gear in case of emergency is by gravity free fall. This is common for large aircraft as their gear are very heavy. Unfortunately, in light aircraft, the gear components are not as heavy, so can get jammed in place with not very much force. This includes the "blowdown" system using compressed gasses. The action of emergency gear extension is often a one-way movement, and cannot be reversed. In order to activate the system, the aircraft will have an emergency release handle in the cockpit which connects to the gear up locks through one of the following systems. When operating the handles, the up-locks will be released, either by mechanical, electrical or pneumatic means. This allows each landing gear to free-fall under its own weight. Some emergency extension systems (as mentioned above) use bottles of compressed air or compressed nitrogen to extend the gear, thereby overcoming any small jams that would otherwise keep the gear in the up position. Nitrogen is better as it is non-flammable, and air contains oxygen, which will feed a potential fire. Compressed air is easier (and cheaper) to bottle though. The gear will remain in the down and locked position because of the mechanical down locks that come into place automatically. The doors will not retract after this, as there is no available system to do so, so they remain in the down position. The shuttle valve mentioned in this question is a way to feed one actuator with two different pressure sources. When one pressure source loses pressure, the piston can slide across from blocking the emergency source to blocking the usual source, allowing out the emergency pressure to feed the actuator. This can be automatic or manually controlled. A diagram of the shuttle valve is shown in the annex above.

options.B: Increased on the slower turning wheels.
options.C: Decreased on the slower turning wheels.
options.D: Decreased on the faster turning wheels.

key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value
Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel
The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU)
learning.explanation: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value. Anti-skid system operations are based on tachometers called wheel speed sensors that measure the rotation speed of each wheel. The tachometers are connected to a computer called anti-skid unit (ASU). The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. When a wheel begins to turn too slowly, brake pressure to this wheel is reduced. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question: The retraction mechanism of the landing gear is...

options.A: an active system and operated with the engine pump.
options.B: an active system and operated with the pressure pump.
options.C: a passive system and operated with the engine pump.
options.D: a passive system and operated with the pressure pump.

key_points: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it
The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively
The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps
learning.explanation: In all aircraft, the landing gear is an active system, in that it requires a power source to function, in this case, it is hydraulic pressure that powers it. The landing gear in some aircraft can be lowered passively (gravity extension), but cannot be raised passively. The power for the hydraulic system in all large aircraft comes from engine driven pumps. These pumps are driven by the auxiliary gearbox connected to one of the engine shafts. Electric hydraulic pumps are also present, and provide the same amount of pressure, but have a much lower displacement as they are much smaller, weaker pumps. Therefore, when landing gear is raised, the vast majority of the load is placed on the engine driven pumps, and is therefore fed by power from the auxiliary gearbox.

However, if the runway is contaminated and has slippery spots, brakes might be released in order to prevent skidding. Brake release will consequently reduce deceleration rate. The autobrake cannot control the aircraft laterally, so it would be really bad if the wheels locked up (on a wet runway without anti-skid), and therefore it cannot be used at all if anti-skid is not available. The sidewall is the bit on the side of the tyre that connects the tread to the "bead", which is fitted to the wheel rim, it is a very vulnerable section of the tyre, with less protection. Objects embedded in the tyre cause obvious damage to the structural integrity, which could lead to blow outs or slow punctures, both of which are very bad for any ground movements, take off and landing. key_points: Anti-skid systems have several functions, but most importantly, they help braking by maintaining an optimum wheel-slip value

The ASU, by comparing the aircraft ground speed as a reference with precise wheel RPM measurements from tachometers, determines the slip ratio required for optimum braking. Operative anti-skid results in shorter landing distances, but also enhances take-off performance by reducing the accelerate-stop distance.

content.question:
Which of the following is correct about multi-disc steel brakes as opposed to single disc carbon brakes?
1. Multiple small applications is best
2. Small numbers of strong applications is best
3. They operate best at a higher brake temperature
4. They operate best at a lower brake temperature
5. They have higher braking strength
6. They have lower braking strength

options.A: 1, 3 and 4
options.B: 2, 4 and 6
options.C: 1, 4 and 5
options.D: 1, 3 and 5

key_points: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received

The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes
Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes
learning.explanation: Important Note: This question is slightly modified from the original feedback received. The original feedback did not compare the multi-disk steel brakes to anything, so was very difficult to answer as the options require comparison to other brakes, however, it was clear from the options that sometimes the examiner was asking about the multi-disk vs single disk element, and sometimes about steel brakes vs carbon brakes. Therefore, We chose to compare them to single disc carbon brakes. The only difference in answer can occur if they compare multi-disc steel brakes to multi-disc carbon brakes directly, in which case the carbon brakes have higher braking strength usually. Please let us know what was actually on the exam if you do see this, and we can adjust it as necessary, thanks! The two usual materials for aircraft brakes are steel and carbon. They vary somewhat in characteristics, and in cost. Steel brakes are usually much cheaper than carbon brakes. Steel brakes perform better at lower temperatures, and when they get hot, suffer from brake fade, where the rotors do not apply as much traction onto the stators due to the intense heat. Carbon brakes, however, have a much hotter operating window. In fact, carbon brakes are not very effective at low temperatures, so need to have some heat in them already, to be able to produce the peak braking force. This is why the two types should be treated differently. Steel brakes should be kept cool, by using them many times, but softly with gaps to allow them to cool. Carbon brakes, on the other hand, should be applied firmly all at once when possible, to allow them to work in their operating window as much as possible, and because their wear is more linked to amount of applications, rather than total heat input. In most transport aircraft, the brakes need to absorb vast amounts of heat during landings, rejected take-offs and taxiing, much more than could be absorbed by a single disk and pair of brake pads. Therefore, their brakes are usually made up of multiple (spinning) brake discs separated by multiple (static) rings of brake pads. These multiple rings of stators and rotors can provide much stronger braking and absorb far more heat than a single disc and pair of pads alone, steel or carbon.

key_points: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation
Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc
Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion
learning.explanation: Pre-flight inspections must confirm whether the condition of the tyre is suitable for operation. Tyre covers must be examined for cuts, bulges, embedded stones, metal or glass, signs of wear, creep, local sponginess, etc. Operation with damaged tyres may result in tyre burst that can cause further damage to the airframe or lead to a ground collision/runway excursion. The defects which may make the cover unserviceable are: Cuts. Cuts in the tyre cover penetrating to the cords render the tyre unserviceable and must be repaired. Bulges. These may indicate partial failure of the casing, if the casing has failed. Foreign Bodies. Embedded stones, metal, glass etc. These must NOT be removed but reported to maintenance staff. Wear. Pattern tread covers worn to the base of the marker grooves or marker tie bars for 25% of the tyre circumference, or plain tread covers worn to the casing fabric, must not be used. Creep. Movement of the tyre round the wheel must not exceed 1 in for tyres of up to 24 in outside diameter and 1 1⁄2 in for tyres over 24 in outside diameter. If these limits are exceeded, the tyre must be removed from the wheel and the tube examined for signs of tearing at the valve. A check of the ply/speed rating, tread depth measurement, and tyre pressure measurement is usually the job of an engineer, and is not required before every single flight, however checking tyre creep and embedded objects are quick enough, and important enough tasks to require a check of every tyre before flight.

content.question:
The autobrake system is deactivated:
1) below a preset minimum speed
2) when reverse thrust is activated

options.B: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect
options.C: 1) is correct, 2) is correct

key_points: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed
Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed
Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated
learning.explanation: The autobrake system is deactivated: Statement 1: below a preset minimum speed. Incorrect, the autobrake will not deactivate below a certain speed. Statement 2: when reverse thrust is activated. Incorrect, the autobrake remains active also when reverse thrust is activated. The auto-brake system can be used for automated braking during landing or during a rejected take-off (RTO). There are several modes the auto-brakes can be in: Off Armed the auto-brake system is ready to be used but there are conditions which have to be met before the auto-brakes start operating. Activated When the system was armed and the necessary conditions have been met the system can be activated in different ways depending on the type of aircraft. The auto-brake system is not useable when the alternate braking system is in use. Depending on the type of aircraft, 3 to 5 modes of deceleration can be selected. Anti-skid protection is provided during autobrake operation, with inoperative anti-skid the auto-brake system will not operate. The autobrakes will be armed once a deceleration mode has been selected. When the aircraft touches down and the main wheels spin up or by the means of weight on wheels the auto-land system will be activated. The auto-land system continues to brake until a complete stop or until the auto-brakes are disarmed. The selected deceleration mode will give a standard deceleration rate independent on the weight of the aircraft for a dry runway. Disarming of the autobrakes will occur by any of the following crew actions: Manual braking Advancing any thrust lever after landing Moving the speed brake lever to down after speed brakes have been deployed on the ground. Moving the autobrake selector to Disarm or Off. When RTO is selected, the maximum brake pressure will be applied when all thrust levers a closed above a ground speed of 85 knots. So below this 85 knots the autobrakes are not activated.

key_points: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording
The answer is quite similar

Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to Q218296, but we have had a couple of reports from UK exams of slight differences in wording. The answer is quite similar. Please let us know if you see either in the exam, and whatever you can remember about them, thank you! FLY-BY-WIRE In a Fly-By-Wire aircraft, the pilot inputs commands via a sidestick or yoke to a computer. The computer then processes these inputs and sends corresponding electrical signals to the servo valve which in turn controls the movement of a hydraulic actuator, moving the flight control surface. There are numerous advantages to fly by wire systems, including weight savings and safety features that can be incorporated into the computer software. FBW enables highly reliable flight envelope protection systems which significantly enhances safety. For instance, on the Airbus, the flight mode of Normal Law provides five types of protection: pitch attitude, load factor limitations, high speed, high-AoA and bank angle. In addition, Low Speed Protection is available in certain phases of flight. The bank angle protection system on a FBW aircraft can change the effect of control inputs to make it harder to maintain a bank angle that is outside of limits. For instance, in the Airbus A320, above 33°, force is needed to maintain the bank angle. The aircraft will not allow bank angles past 67° in normal law. In this question the bank angle protections have activated improperly at 30° AoB, so more force will be required to maintain or increase the angle of bank.

content.question: In a fully manual flight control system, the pilot must exert sufficient force to...

options.A: separate each pilot`s yaw control in the case of a jam.
options.B: overcome the aerodynamic loads felt at the control surface.
options.C: activate the artificial feel system.
options.D: allow pressure to build up in the flight control actuators.

key_points: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls
So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
learning.explanation: As a fully manual flight control system is reversible the pilot feels all forces acting on the control surfaces in the controls. So the pilot must be able to exert sufficient force to overcome the aerodynamic loads on the control surfaces. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.02: List the following secondary flight control surfaces: lift-augmentation devices (flaps and slats); speed brakes; flight and ground spoilers; trimming devices such as trim tabs, trimmable horizontal stabiliser. Secondary flight controls are surfaces which aid the characteristics of the aircraft and the pilots, but are not the primary control surfaces. content.question: What happens to the flight envelope protection if your aircraft system turns to the Alternate mode?

options.A: degraded.
options.B: fully maintained.
options.C: lost.
options.D: upgraded.

key_points: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft
Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use
The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law
learning.explanation: EASA examinations use the Airbus A320 family as an example of Fly-By-Wire controlled aircraft. Normal law is the system mode which is active throughout the flight and is terminated when system failures occur that prevent its use. The highest reduced mode of operation in Airbus FBW systems is the Alternate Law, which provides most features of normal law. Some features such as automatic stall protection are lost and replaced by conventional warnings for the pilots to manually correct the condition. This means that flight envelope protection is degraded as avionics no longer limit the pilot input to avoid stall. Should failure conditions prevent operation in Alternate Law, an even more basic Direct Law is available. Autopilot functions are lost, along with flight envelope protection. As a last emergency means of operation, Mechanical Backup is provided to maintain level flight only for the limited period of flight control computer reset following a complete loss of power. As we have stated above, a system degradation results in a loss of protection features, so the required alertness of the crew increases and leads to a higher workload.

The use of more than 1 actuator per control surface

There can be two systems powering the same surface, where one is a back-up for the other and can be used with the use of clutches on the same control run. The use of more than 1 actuator per control surface. The use of multiple control surfaces per axis, for example, spoilers can also be used for lateral control when the ailerons would fail.

key_points: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts

learning.explanation: Flaps There are numerous types of flap designs which increase lift and drag in varying amounts. For light aircraft the most popular type is the plain or camber flap. For large transport aircraft the most used is the slotted Fowler flaps. (see different types in the image in the annex) In the cockpit there will be a selector where the pilot selects the desired flap setting, the input from this selector will be the input for the slat/flap control computers which control, test and monitor the operation of the flaps and slats. This computer’s output will be the input for an electrically controlled hydro-mechanical unit, a hydraulic motor, which drive the transmission which moves the flaps. The position of the flaps is measured with sensors and is indicated in the cockpit. The flaps are protected against asymmetric operation, runaway and over speed. The flap load relief system, or load limiter will retract the flaps to an intermediate position when the airspeed exceeds a predetermined speed. Once the speed has decreased below this speed, the flaps will be automatically returned to the selected flap setting. If the main hydraulic system fails, the emergency operation might be via an alternate hydraulic system or an electric motor which operates the same gear train as the normal operating system.

Thankfully, this topic is not particularly complicated so the more questions about this, the better
In a fly-by-wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system
learning.explanation: Note: There are lots of questions on the bank about this, and some very similar looking ones to this, but different feedback has indicated different options, so we will continue to add as many new questions as we think are in the real exams. Thankfully, this topic is not particularly complicated so the more questions about this, the better. In a fly-by-wire system such as the Airbus A320, amongst others, both pilots have a sidestick which is a major input into the fly-by-wire control system. As these sidesticks are not mechanically linked like other, there needs to be a way for both pilots to make inputs at once. The standard system for this is for both inputs to be "algebraically summed" together, which is a complex way of saying that both sticks get an input into the control system. This is called dual input. In case that it occurs, an aural warning “DUAL INPUT” and a flashing warning light in sight of each pilot is provided. To allow one pilot to take over controls from the other, which might be necessary in case of incapacitation, etc., a red take-over button is installed on each sidestick that disables the stick on the other side when held. This button works as an autopilot disconnect when pushed once, but when it is pushed and held, it removes the other pilot's inputs from the system, and after 40 seconds of holding (A320 specific) the other pilot is "locked out" from inputs until they push their own priority button. When this condition occurs, an aural warning is provided “PRIORITY LEFT/RIGHT”, indicating the active sidestick.

content.question: On an aircraft equipped with a Fly-By-Wire control system, the pilot…

options.A: never override soft and hard protections.
options.B: can override hard protections only.
options.C: can override soft protections only.
options.D: can override soft and hard protections.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer
The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made
CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE (FBW) Fly-By-Wire aeroplanes function differently to conventional aeroplanes in that the pilot or autopilot input is via a flight control computer. The computer translates this input into an aircraft attitude using all three axes, which it will then maintain until another input is made. CONTROL LAWS - NORMAL LAW The Fly-By-Wire system was designed and certified to render the new generation of aircraft even more safe, cost effective, and pleasant to fly. Flight control surfaces are all : ‐ Electrically-controlled ‐ Hydraulically-actuated. Computers interpret pilot input and move the flight control surfaces, as necessary, to follow their orders. However, when in normal law, regardless of the pilot’s input, the computers will prevent excessive manoeuvres and exceedance of the safe envelope in pitch and roll axis. One of the PF's primary tasks is to maintain the aircraft within the limits of the normal flight envelope. Some circumstances, due to extreme situations or aircraft mishandling, may provoke the violation of these limits. Protections are intended to: - Provide maximum authority to the PF to consistently achieve the best possible aircraft performance in extreme conditions - Reduce the risks of over-controlling, or over-stressing the aircraft - Provide PF with an instinctive and immediate procedure to ensure that the PF achieves the best possible result. The normal law protects the aircraft throughout the flight envelope, as follows: ‐ load factor limitation ‐ pitch attitude protection ‐ high-speed protection. - bank angle protection ‐ high-angle-of-attack (AoA) protection One of the hard protections on the Airbus system, in normal law, is the stall protection. Without flight crew input, the F/CTL computers maintain the AoA equal to a defined value. The AoA can be further increased by flight crew input, up to a maximum value. The AoA will not exceed that maximum value, even if the flight crew gently pulls the sidestick all the way back. CONTROL LAWS - RECONFIGURATION LAWS Depending on the failures occurring to the flight control system, or on its peripherals, there are 3 levels of reconfiguration : ‐ Alternate law (There are two levels of alternate law : with and without reduced protections.) ‐ Direct law ‐ Mechanical ALTERNATE LAW - REDUCED PROTECTIONS - Load Factor Limitation - Pitch Attitude Protection - Low Speed Stability (Soft protection) An artificial low speed stability replaces the normal angle-of-attack protection. A gentle progressive nose down signal is introduced, that tends to keep the speed from falling below these values. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, stall warnings are activated at an appropriate margin from the stall condition. - High Speed Stability (Soft protection) Above VMO or MMO, a nose up demand is introduced to avoid an excessive increase in speed. The flight crew can override this demand. In addition, the aural overspeed warning remains available.
