key_points: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge
The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges
In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero
learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges. In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

key_points: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start
This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air
When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks
learning.explanation: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start. This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air. When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks. In fact, the mass flow of air will be reduced, which will increase the engine’s overall temperature, especially the turbine temperature since less air is available for cooling. It also increases specific fuel consumption and the EGT and the power output (or thrust) will be decreased, in other words, aircraft, and more precisely engine performance will greatly be decreased. Because of all this, it is normal to see PACKS OFF take-off, since all the available power is needed during this critical stage of the flight. Conducting a PACKS OFF take-off also has the advantage of reducing the required thrust and the noise footprint.

learning.explanation: ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS Two major categories of ice control systems are pneumatic boots – which expand and break ice off aerofoils; and thermal systems – which use bleed air or electricity to heat protected surfaces and prevent ice. AEROFOIL ICE CONTROL To protect wing and tail surface leading edges from icing, most aeroplanes use pneumatic devices. On many reciprocating-engine and turboprop airplanes, de-icing boots are pneumatically inflated for a few seconds to break the ice, which allows it to be carried away by the airstream. This system can be triggered from the flight deck. In another system, primarily used by turbine-powered aeroplanes, heated air is directed through ducting in the aerofoil leading edge, to thermally prevent ice from forming. key_points: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as a differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge
The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges

learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as a differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges. In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

key_points: We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel

learning.explanation: We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel. We need it to have a low freezing point, so the fuel does not freeze in the tanks when at cruising level with a very low outside air temperature. We also require a flash point high enough that the fuel will not be able to burn on the ground, whilst refuelling etc. Jet A has a freezing point of -40°C Jet A1 is very similar but with some additives, to make the freezing point -47°C, which is slightly better. Jet B is much rarer, but is used for aircraft that operate in very cold climates, and has a freezing point of -60°C. Jet B has a lower freezing point, but also a lower flash point, meaning that it could set on fire if lit at normal ground temperatures. This is why it is known as a "wide cut fuel", and it is not approved for commercial air transport in the EU. Jet A and Jet A1 have a minimum flash point of 38°C, which means that they are not too likely to be flammable during refuelling, etc.

content.question: A four-engined jet transport aircraft experiences an engine failure, but there is no immediate need to land and the aircraft is at a safe altitude and airspeed. Which of the following safety measures could be considered?

options.A: Begin dumping fuel, if the aircraft is equipped with a fuel jettison system, to reduce weight and balance the aircraft.
options.B: Switch all fuel pumps on to avoid fuel starvation to any remaining three engines.
options.C: Reduce altitude to increase the efficiency of the remaining engines and decrease the fuel burn.
options.D: Increase airspeed to compensate for the loss of thrust and maintain stability.

key_points: Engine failures are not always emergency situations
In a 4-engine aircraft, the loss of one engine means you now have a little thrust assymetry and 75% of the aircraft's maximum thrust avialable
If at cruising level, this might not be enough to maintain altitude, and a drift-down procedure may be required
learning.explanation: Engine failures are not always emergency situations. In a 4-engine aircraft, the loss of one engine means you now have a little thrust assymetry and 75% of the aircraft's maximum thrust avialable. If at cruising level, this might not be enough to maintain altitude, and a drift-down procedure may be required. Remember that this is a lot less bad than losing one engine out of two. One thing to think about is that the right hand engines are usually fed from the right hand wing tanks, and the left hand engines from the left wing tanks. If an engine fails and the aircraft is not going to land immediately, then it is a good idea to make sure all available fuel pumps are on and open up the crossfeed valve (if available) to make sure that the engines all have access to fuel, and that one tank does not run dry before the others. This also helps to keep the aircraft balanced. None of the other options are really necessary in the situation, and descending would make the engines less fuel efficient (though would allow for higher thrust output).

options.B: The dielectric change between fuel and air.
options.C: The electrical resistance change.
options.D: The resistivity variation of the fuel.

key_points: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. As you can imagine, the area of the plates and the distance between is not going to change over time, they’re fixed. So, the only variable is going to be the dielectric. Therefore, the amount of fuel and air between the plates, which is continuously changing as fuel is consumed, controls the quantity indication.

content.question: Regarding gravity-fed fuel tanks, which of the following statements is correct?

options.B: The fuel tank must be located below the engine.
options.C: The fuel tank can be at the same level as the engine.
options.D: The fuel tank should be placed in the tail section of the aircraft.

key_points: This is a simple question

For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity
The fuel must therefore be stored above the carburettor and engine, such as in a high wing aircraft like a Cessna 152
learning.explanation: This is a simple question. For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity. The fuel must therefore be stored above the carburettor and engine, such as in a high wing aircraft like a Cessna 152. The weight of fuel on the rest of the fuel in the lines is what pushes it through the lines into the carburettor (for a carburetted engine). If the engine was injected, a high pressure pump would be required before the injector to provide the injection pressure, but the system could still be “gravity fed”.

learning.explanation: The HP fuel pump receives fuel from the LP fuel filter, strategically placed to prevent debris from entering the pumps or other system components. These filters are typically installed at the fuel tank outlet. Subsequently, the HP fuel pump elevates the fuel pressure to fulfill the requirements of the engine-driven fuel pump and fuel injectors. Meanwhile, the FUEL CONTROL UNIT (FCU) acts as a precise fuel metering device, regulating fuel flow to the engine. Due to their high precision, it's crucial for the fuel supplied to them to be clean and free of contaminants. Micronic filters, positioned before the FCU, ensure this cleanliness. These fuel filters are positioned upstream of the FCU to safeguard the delicate components within both the HP fuel pump and the FCU. content.question:
Which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
1. In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel
2. In gas turbine engines, fuel tanks must be in low wing configuration

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel
- incorrect In piston-engine aircraft, fuel can be supplied to the engine through either gravity-fed or pump-fed systems
learning.explanation: 1. In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel. - incorrect In piston-engine aircraft, fuel can be supplied to the engine through either gravity-fed or pump-fed systems. Gravity-fed fuel systems are typically found in high-wing aircraft, where the fuel tanks are positioned above the engine. Gravity allows the fuel to flow naturally from the tanks to the engine without the need for fuel pumps. However, many piston-engine aircraft, especially those with low-wing configurations, use fuel pumps because the fuel tanks are located below the engine. In these cases, mechanical or electric fuel pumps are essential to supply fuel to the engine. Therefore, it is not mandatory for piston-engine fuel supplies to be gravity-fed; the fuel supply method depends on the aircraft's design. 2. In gas turbine engines, fuel tanks must be in low wing configuration. - incorrect Gas turbine engine aircraft can have fuel tanks in various configurations, not exclusively in low-wing designs. While many jet aircraft feature low-wing configurations with fuel tanks integrated into the wings, there are numerous exceptions. High-wing aircraft, such as some turboprop and cargo planes (e.g., the C-130 Hercules), also use gas turbine engines and have fuel tanks located in the wings or fuselage. The placement of fuel tanks in gas turbine engine aircraft is determined by factors like aircraft size, purpose, and design requirements—not solely by the engine type. Therefore, it is not a necessity for gas turbine engine fuel tanks to be in a low-wing configuration.

content.question: What is the safest method to prime a piston engine aircraft before starting?

options.A: By injecting neat fuel into the inlet manifold.
options.B: Injection of fuel through the spark plug hole.
options.C: Pumping the throttle.
options.D: Rotate the propeller with the throttle fully open.

key_points: Note: This question is almost exactly the same as question 218090, but the correct answer is very slightly different
The answer to question 218090 is slightly more correct in our opinion, but this one is also sufficiently correct, in comparison to the other options
The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the induction manifold
learning.explanation: Note: This question is almost exactly the same as question 218090, but the correct answer is very slightly different. The answer to question 218090 is slightly more correct in our opinion, but this one is also sufficiently correct, in comparison to the other options. The priming system consists of a priming pump that will deliver fuel to the induction manifold. Its whole purpose is to inject additional fuel in the cylinders intake ports to assist the engine start. As this extra fuel now lines the intake ports/inlet manifold to one or more of the cylinders, and is very volatile, it will evaporate into the air flowing into the cylinders, giving the necessary fuel/air mixture to start the engine. The "inlet manifold" is the area just before the intake air gets split up to each individual cylinder, so priming this area will prime the fuel to all cylinders, but we consider this to be almost exactly the same meaning as injecting fuel into the intake ports. In the absence of such a system, it is possible (but more likely to cause a fire hazard) to deliver more fuel to the cylinders by pumping the throttle lever which will act on the accelerator pump and deliver more fuel from the carburettor. Unfortunately, this method coats the earlier intake lines with fuel, and may therefore catch fire unintentionally if the excess fuel drips onto hot components, etc. The priming pump may be electrical or manual, and will be fitted in parallel with the main fuel pump (which is either electric or mechanical) and will take fuel from the filter housing and channel it to the nozzles at the inlet manifold/intake ports. The necessary amount of priming required will mainly depend on the ambient temperature and how long the engine hasn’t been running. Priming is mostly necessary for the first flight of the day and during cold weather after the engine has been off for a few hours (depending on the engine type). However, sometimes it is not even needed as the engine will perfectly start without priming. Over-priming a hot engine could lead to a buildup of excessive fuel inside the cylinders (flooding), potentially increasing the risk of engine fire, flooding the engine, and fouling the spark plugs. Whilst pumping the throttle can work, it is not really made for "priming", more providing extra fuel to the engine once running, and is therefore not preferred. There is no hole in the spark plug for fuel, and please, please don't rotate a propeller with the throttle wide open. If the magnetos are unintentionally on or the engine has a hot spot then a cylinder could fire and cause serious injury.

options.B: Wrinkles at the bottom can cause part of the fuel to be considered unusable.
options.C: It is not possible to fully drain them to perform maintenance.
options.D: They are not accessible for maintenance as they are part of the airframe.

key_points: Note: This question isn't very good, and there are two slightly correct answers here (none that we consider fully correct), but we believe that one is more correct than the other

AIRCRAFT FUEL TANKS INTEGRAL TANKS: Integral Tanks are used on all modern large passenger aircraft and, as its name suggests, a tank is formed as an unit within the airframe structure by sealing part of the structure of the wings or fuselage with a fuel resistant two-part sealant
The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings
learning.explanation: Note: This question isn't very good, and there are two slightly correct answers here (none that we consider fully correct), but we believe that one is more correct than the other. AIRCRAFT FUEL TANKS INTEGRAL TANKS: Integral Tanks are used on all modern large passenger aircraft and, as its name suggests, a tank is formed as an unit within the airframe structure by sealing part of the structure of the wings or fuselage with a fuel resistant two-part sealant. The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings. Aircraft with integral fuel tanks in the wings are said to have "wet wings". RIGID TANKS: A rigid tank is a sealed metal container strapped into a compartment designed to accommodate the tank in the airframe structure. They are simple and may be removed for inspection, replacement, or repair. However, this type of tank adds extra weight. They are common on light aircraft. FLEXIBLE TANKS/FUEL BLADDERS: Flexible tanks are reinforced rubberized bags installed in a section of the aircraft structure designed to accommodate the weight of the fuel. A bladder tank contains most of the features and components of a rigid tank but does not require as large an opening in the aircraft skin to install. It is rolled up and installed into the compartment through the fuel filler neck or access panel, and is secured by means of metal buttons or snaps inside the compartment. One major down-side to this type of tank is the tendency for materials to work harden through extensive use making them brittle causing cracks. So out of these options then, both mentioning maintenance are incorrect. Fuel bladder tanks are great for maintenance as they can be removed completely if necessary. Of the other two options, "easily punctured" is neither fully correct nor incorrect, as yes, they can be punctured, of course, but they are often made puncture resistant and may even be self-sealing against punctures. The wrinkles are the only potential problem here, and whilst they are relatively unlikely due to the fixing of the bladder to the aircraft structure, badly designed or incorrectly fixed tanks could easily wrinkle, at which point a few precious litres of fuel become unusable by the engines, and this is certainly a problem.

options.B: The fuel tanks must be located above the carburettor to provide the correct pressure.
options.C: The engine cannot be fuel injected.
options.D: It needs an electric pump to operate.

key_points: Note: A few similar questions to this have been reported recently, but this one is the least confirmed, so please provide any further feedback you have about this question from the real exam
Given the statements, we think the question will be laid out in this way, but this is not assured yet
It could also be a choice of which statements are correct (1, 2 and 4, etc
learning.explanation: Note: A few similar questions to this have been reported recently, but this one is the least confirmed, so please provide any further feedback you have about this question from the real exam. Given the statements, we think the question will be laid out in this way, but this is not assured yet. It could also be a choice of which statements are correct (1, 2 and 4, etc.) with different wording for the statements. For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity. The fuel must therefore be stored above the carburettor and engine, such as in a high wing aircraft like a Cessna 152. The weight of fuel on the rest of the fuel in the lines is what pushes it into the carburettor (for a carburetted engine). If the engine was injected, a high pressure pump would be required before the injector to provide the injection pressure, but the system could still be “gravity fed”. As for the other options; A fuel gauge is just as required as it would be in any fuel system. In fact, in some gravity fed aircraft, you can actually see the fuel in the tanks, so they act as their own fuel gauges. We're not sure if the examiner is saying that gravity fed aircraft don't need fuel gauges, or they don't need them any more that pump-fed aircraft do. As mentioned above, the engine could still be fuel injected. The fuel would be gravity fed from the tanks to the high pressure pump just before the fuel injectors. We would say that this is not "true" gravity feeding, but it seems to still count, particularly as a low pressure pump is not required to get the fuel out of the tanks. They don't need an electric fuel pump to operate (but may have a boost pump fitted for crucial phases of flight).

content.question: What are the advantages of a pressure feed fuel system?

options.A: Reduced weight, higher manoeuvrability and increased flexibility in design.
options.B: Increased simplicity, independence from power sources, better flexibility in design and higher reliability.
options.C: More consistent fuel flow, better flexibility in design and higher manoeuvrability.
options.D: Increased simplicity, more consistent fuel flow, reduced weight and independence from power sources.

key_points: A pressure feed fuel system means that fuel is taken from the tank and pumped under pressure to the engines
This means that the fuel tanks can be located underneath the engines, and that any engine can be fed from any tank, via pressurised crossfeeding
This is particularly useful with multi-engine aircraft which can have engine failures, to allow fuel balancing in that eventuality
learning.explanation: A pressure feed fuel system means that fuel is taken from the tank and pumped under pressure to the engines. This means that the fuel tanks can be located underneath the engines, and that any engine can be fed from any tank, via pressurised crossfeeding. This is particularly useful with multi-engine aircraft which can have engine failures, to allow fuel balancing in that eventuality. Pressure feed fuel systems are the opposite of purely gravity fed fuel systems, where the tank must be sufficiently over the engine to push the fuel through the lines to the engine. Pressure feed systems have a few advantages over gravity fed fuel systems: The aircraft can be more manoeuvrable as the fuel feeding will not stop if the local gravity changes (during harsh manoeuvres). The fuel flow is more consistent due to higher pressure, less chance of vapour lock and also during manoeuvring the fuel flow will not cut out. The fuel tanks can be anywhere in the aircraft and be pumped to engines which can be anywhere, unlike gravity fed systems which have obviously very strict requirements. Fuel can also be cross-fed, etc. to balance tanks. This makes the aircraft design much more flexible. Disadvantages of pressure feed systems include the fact that gravity fed systems are less complex and therefore reduce weight. They are also not reliant on electric or engine driven fuel pumps.

content.question: What is the purpose of fuel tank vents?

options.A: To allow for fuel tank drainage and fuel sampling.
options.B: To allow excess fuel to be removed.
options.C: To prevent a vacuum forming in the tanks in flight.
options.D: To prevent fuel freezing during flight at low temperatures.

key_points: FUEL VENT SYSTEM Fuel tank vents allow air into the fuel tank to replace the volume of fuel consumed by the engine and to allow for equalization of pressure as the aircraft climbs or descends which helps to reduce evaporation and aids fuel transfer
This stops a small vacuum effect (suction) from occuring in the tank when the fuel is burnt in flight

Fuel vents also usually use the speed of the airflow (ram effect) to provide a positive "head of pressure" on the fuel, to improve the performance of the initial fuel pumps and reduce the potential for cavitation
learning.explanation: FUEL VENT SYSTEM Fuel tank vents allow air into the fuel tank to replace the volume of fuel consumed by the engine and to allow for equalization of pressure as the aircraft climbs or descends which helps to reduce evaporation and aids fuel transfer. This stops a small vacuum effect (suction) from occuring in the tank when the fuel is burnt in flight. Fuel vents also usually use the speed of the airflow (ram effect) to provide a positive "head of pressure" on the fuel, to improve the performance of the initial fuel pumps and reduce the potential for cavitation. When the fuel tanks are located in the wings, the fuel-tank vent will typically have a forward-facing ram tube or hole in the wing to provide ram airflow. The ram air intakes are located on the underside of the wing.

content.question: Which of the following fuel types is best suited to extremely cold weather operations with gas turbine engines?

options.A: Jet A
options.B: Jet A-1
options.C: Jet B
options.D: AVGAS

key_points: Note: we have limited feedback on this question, so please let us know in the comments if you see it in the real exam, thank you! We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel
We need it to have a low freezing point, so the fuel does not freeze in the tanks when at cruising level with a very low outside air temperature
We also prefer it to have a flash point high enough that the fuel will not be able to burn on the ground, whilst refuelling etc
learning.explanation: Note: we have limited feedback on this question, so please let us know in the comments if you see it in the real exam, thank you! We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel. We need it to have a low freezing point, so the fuel does not freeze in the tanks when at cruising level with a very low outside air temperature. We also prefer it to have a flash point high enough that the fuel will not be able to burn on the ground, whilst refuelling etc. Jet A has a freezing point of -40°C Jet A-1 is very similar but with some additives, to make the freezing point -47°C, which is slightly better. Jet B is much rarer, but is used for aircraft that operate in very cold climates, and has a freezing point of -60°C. Jet B has a lower freezing point, but also a lower flash point, meaning that it could set on fire if lit at normal ground temperatures. This is why it is known as a "wide cut fuel", and it is not approved for commercial air transport in the EU. Jet A and Jet A-1 have a minimum flash point of 38°C, which means that they are not too likely to be flammable during refuelling, etc. AVGAS is not suitable for use in gas turbine engines.

options.A: No, all the fuel will be removed from the tanks.
options.B: Yes, there will still be enough fuel remaining for approach and landing, and the pilots can close it.
options.C: No. It will cause excessive weight and adversely affect the aircraft’s performance.
options.D: Yes. The aircraft will still be within safe weight and balance limits, regardless of the fuel dumped.

learning.explanation: Note: We have only received one count of feedback for this question so far, and it would be very useful to get more feedback to try and confirm the wording and answer here. As yet we are happy with this as the correct answer, but confirmation would be very useful, thank you! The wording of this question is very misleading in our opinion, as without type-specific knowledge, this is very difficult to answer, but we will try and give you the best information we can. Fuel jettisoning systems are required on an aircraft when there is a large difference between the maximum take-off weight (MTOW) and the maximum landing weight (MLW). For a B737 for instance, there is a large difference between these two figures, however overweight landings are approved up to the MTOW of the aircraft if necessary, so no fuel jettison system is required, as any issues in flight, the crew can just perform an overweight landing as soon as necessary. On a larger aircraft, however, the maximum landing weight can be 100 tonnes less than the MTOW, so fuel jettison systems are necessary. Fuel jettison systems are obviously an inherent threat, as anything that removes fuel (and therefore airborne time) from the aircraft is at a high risk of a small error having big consequences. This is why there are protections in place. For starters, jettison systems are usually separate systems from those which feed the engines. Checking some aircraft types which have fuel jettisoning, the B777 has separate jettison pumps that go through specific jettison lines to the jettison valves, and the A340 has jettison valves placed on the refuelling/transfer system. This means that there is no single point of failure which causes unwanted jettisoning of fuel, as if the valves became fixed open, the pumps could be switched off, etc. We have been able to attach a replication of the fuel schematic for a 4 engine aircraft above, notice that the two fuel systems (refuelling/transfer/jettison vs the engine feed) are separate. Also, there is a further method of protection in the tanks, and there is usually a standpipe or other mechanical method that prevents fuel being jettisoned below a certain fuel tank level. This means that there is always enough fuel left for approach and landing (likely also a missed approach), even if the fuel jettison system got rid of everything. This protects for multiple system failures and some amount of human error.

content.question: Vapour lock can occur when the pressure in the fuel system is (1) _____, which allows fuel to (2) _____, forming a bubble which (3) _____ the flow of fuel through the lines.

options.A: (1) high; (2) boil; (3) accelerates
options.B: (1) high; (2) boil; (3) blocks
options.C: (1) low; (2) solidify; (3) blocks
options.D: (1) low; (2) boil; (3) blocks

key_points: ‘Vapour lock’ is the phenomenon by which fuel vapor bubbles block the fuel feed line
In fact, it is mainly caused by the fuel vaporising prior to it entering the engine

It vapourises because the fuel pressure is too low, and this allows the molecules to very easily break apart into a gas (remember that some types of fuel are very volatile and prone to becoming a gas anyway)
learning.explanation: ‘Vapour lock’ is the phenomenon by which fuel vapor bubbles block the fuel feed line. In fact, it is mainly caused by the fuel vaporising prior to it entering the engine. It vapourises because the fuel pressure is too low, and this allows the molecules to very easily break apart into a gas (remember that some types of fuel are very volatile and prone to becoming a gas anyway). This is effectively the same as the fuel "boiling", but due to low pressure rather than very high temperature. This is quite similar to how water boils at a much lower temperature at high altitudes, and you'll struggle to get a good cup of tea on top of Mount Everest, as the water never gets hot enough, boiling at around 65ºC. Low pressure reduces boiling points, as the molecules don't want to be together as much. To prevent vapour locking and cavitation, a low-pressure pump is fitted to the feed line and will supply fuel from the tanks at suitable pressure and flow. Under certain circumstances when the engine is very hot, vapor lock can also occur in the injector lines and prevent the fuel from being correctly delivered to the cylinders.

content.question: Why are additives used for turbine engine fuels?

options.A: To decrease the flashpoint of the fuel for operation in high temperatures.
options.B: To increase the flashpoint of the fuel for operation in high temperatures.
options.C: To increase the freezing point when operating in low temperatures.
options.D: To prevent waxing of the fuel in low temperatures.

key_points: Additives can be incorporated into the fuel either during refining or at the airfield to enhance its performance
All fuel contains some level of water
Fuel System Icing Inhibitors (FSII) are utilized to lower the freezing point of any water present in the fuel system, thereby preventing the formation of ice crystals that could impede fuel flow
learning.explanation: Additives can be incorporated into the fuel either during refining or at the airfield to enhance its performance. All fuel contains some level of water. Fuel System Icing Inhibitors (FSII) are utilized to lower the freezing point of any water present in the fuel system, thereby preventing the formation of ice crystals that could impede fuel flow. In summary, additives aid in minimizing the formation of ice crystals in cold temperatures. As the fuel is heated en route to the engine, any ice crystals revert to a fluid state, allowing the fuel to be combusted as usual. Note: The terms "waxing" or "gelling" refer to the transformation of jet fuel into a partially crystalline (solid) state under low temperatures.

content.question: Integral fuel tanks…

options.A: comprise a portion of the aircraft structure, which has been sealed to form a fuel tank.
options.B: are small fuel tanks fitted on the engine to ensure a positive supply of fuel to the engine driven fuel pump.
options.C: is an alternate name for a system of bladder tanks installed within the aircraft structure.
options.D: is the name given to a group of fuel tanks where several tanks feed a master tank which in turn supplies the engine.

key_points: AIRCRAFT FUEL TANKS INTEGRAL TANKS: Integral Tanks are used on all modern large passenger aircraft and, as its name suggests, a tank is formed as an unit within the airframe structure by sealing part of the structure of the wings or fuselage with a fuel resistant two-part sealant
The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings
Aircraft with integral fuel tanks in the wings are said to have wet wings
learning.explanation: AIRCRAFT FUEL TANKS INTEGRAL TANKS: Integral Tanks are used on all modern large passenger aircraft and, as its name suggests, a tank is formed as an unit within the airframe structure by sealing part of the structure of the wings or fuselage with a fuel resistant two-part sealant. The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings. Aircraft with integral fuel tanks in the wings are said to have wet wings. RIGID TANKS: A rigid tank is a sealed metal container strapped into a compartment designed to accomodate the tank in the airframe structure. They are simple and may be removed for inspection, replacement, or repair. However, this type of tank adds extra weight. FLEXIBLE TANKS/FUEL BLADDERS: Flexible tanks are reinforced rubberized bags installed in a section of the aircraft structure designed to accommodate the weight of the fuel. A bladder tank contains most of the features and components of a rigid tank but does not require as large an opening in the aircraft skin to install. It is rolled up and installed into the compartment through the fuel filler neck or access panel, and is secured by means of metal buttons or snaps inside the compartment. One major down-side to this type of tank is the tendency for materials to work harden through extensive use making them brittle causing cracks.

content.question: Some aircraft are equipped with fuel tanks for trimming purpose, where are these tanks usually positioned and what are they used for?

options.A: In the rear part of the aircraft, near the tail and used to regulate CG.
options.B: In the front part of the aircraft, near the nose and used for forward CG.
options.C: Near the CG position and used to regulate CG.
options.D: On the wing tip and used for forward CG.

key_points: Often aircraft will have a CG that changes significantly during flight, mostly due to fuel burn

This has an affect on the aircraft's flight characteristics, being that a forward CG requires more nose-up trim, which causes a downforce on the horizontal stabiliser, and therefore means that the main wing is lifting a heavier load
This leads to increased drag (sometimes called trim drag), increased stall speed, lower maximum altitude, etc
learning.explanation: Often aircraft will have a CG that changes significantly during flight, mostly due to fuel burn. This has an affect on the aircraft's flight characteristics, being that a forward CG requires more nose-up trim, which causes a downforce on the horizontal stabiliser, and therefore means that the main wing is lifting a heavier load. This leads to increased drag (sometimes called trim drag), increased stall speed, lower maximum altitude, etc. This is oposed to an aft CG, which reduces all those negative effects, for the trade-off of reduced stability. This makes it useful for us to be able to change the CG of the aircraft so we do not have to contend with as much trim drag. To do this, a trim fuel tank can be fitted in the rear of the aircraft, which is usually tranferred and then burnt at the correct time to ensure peak efficiency, with the best possible CG position. This is the reason they are fitted in the tail of the aircraft, as that is the place furthest away from the CG, to have the greatest effect. An interesting side note, Concorde had such trim tanks in the tail of the aircraft, and fuel would be pumped to them to bring the CG backwards when accelerating through the transonic range, in order to counteract the effects of Mach tuck. This drastically reduced the drag of a conventional Mach trim system, and the reverse would occur when the aircraft decelerated back to subsonic flight again.

Fuel quantity can be measured by:

2. Measuring mass or weight by varying capacitance

options.B: 1) is correct, 2) is correct.
options.C: 1) is correct, 2) is incorrect.
options.D: 1) is incorrect, 2) is incorrect.

key_points: In turbine aircraft, quantity is gauged by measuring weight or mass via capacitance variations
Conversely, light aircraft gauge quantity by measuring volume (in liters and gallons) through the adjustment of resistance using a float
However, this method is susceptible to maneuvering inaccuracies and cannot adjust for density fluctuations
learning.explanation: In turbine aircraft, quantity is gauged by measuring weight or mass via capacitance variations. Conversely, light aircraft gauge quantity by measuring volume (in liters and gallons) through the adjustment of resistance using a float. However, this method is susceptible to maneuvering inaccuracies and cannot adjust for density fluctuations. Further reading: The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. The float-type fuel gauging system consists of a simple mechanical float sitting on the fuel level and linked via a mechanical arm to a gauge indicating the volume. One of the main limitations of the volume indicating systems is that temperature variations will impact the reading of the tanks’ actual fuel quantity. The reading will also be imprecise during maneuvers, accelerations, and turbulence; the reading will only be reliable in straight and level flight.

key_points: This is a pretty simple one

learning.explanation: This is a pretty simple one. For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity. The fuel must therefore be stored above the carburettor and engine, such as in a high wing aircraft like a Cessna 152. The weight of fuel on the rest of the fuel in the lines is what pushes it into the carburettor (for a carburetted engine). If the engine was injected, a high pressure pump would be required before the injector to provide the injection pressure, but the system could still be “gravity fed”. As for the other options, they are just as necessary (or less so) in a gravity fed system as in a fuel pump driven system. Fuel flow and pressure sensors are useful in some systems, but not required in most, and a pressure relief valve is much less required in a gravity fed system as the pressures involved are usually much lower.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Whilst performing an ordinary flight, the pilots notice a fuel imbalance, with the right wing tank holding more fuel than the left wing tank. The crew manage to confirm that there is no fuel leak causing the imbalance. Which of the following should the crew do to restore the aircraft balance?

options.A: Close the cross-feed valve and shut off the left wing tank fuel pump(s).
options.B: Open the cross-feed valve and shut off the right wing tank fuel pump(s).
options.C: Open the cross-feed valve and shut off the left wing tank fuel pump(s).
options.D: Force the cross feed valve to open and wait for the system to equalise.

key_points: The fuel system in the annex is from the Boeing 737, and is representative of many large commercial jet transport aircraft
This question poses the scenario of having low fuel in the left tank for some reason, and asks how to deal with this
Of course, as with any imbalance, crossfeed is usually the way forward
learning.explanation: The fuel system in the annex is from the Boeing 737, and is representative of many large commercial jet transport aircraft. This question poses the scenario of having low fuel in the left tank for some reason, and asks how to deal with this. Of course, as with any imbalance, crossfeed is usually the way forward. It is important to note that crossfeed does not transfer fuel between tanks, but instead allows both engines to be fed from the other tank. By opening the crossfeed valve, either engine can take fuel from either tank, so how do we stop the system from running out of fuel in the left tank? We have to make sure that the pressure of fuel being pumped out of the right tank is significantly higher than the pressure of fuel from the left tank. We do this by turning the Low Pressure AC fuel pumps from the left tank off completely, and leaving the fuel pumps on from the right tank, so the fuel is taken from the right tank as priority. None of this fuel can flow into the left tank due to the non-return valves, so just feeds both engines at once, burning down the amount of fuel in the right tank until the tanks are equal. Note that in the crossfeeding scenario, if the right tank pumps failed, then both engines could be fed from the suction of the HP engine pumps from either tank, without any AC pumps required, it is just less ideal and more prone to problems. Note: do not worry that the cross-feed valve is open in the question figure, it is just a figure to help you see the layout of the fuel system.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.08.02.02.02: Name the main components of the fuel system and state their location and their function: trim fuel tanks; bafflers; refuelling/defueling system; fuel dump/jettison system. Remark: For completion of list, please see 021.08 01.02 (02). Often aircraft will have a CG that changes significantly during flight, mostly due to fuel burn. This has an effect on the aircraft's flight characteristics, being that a forward CG requires more nose-up trim, which causes a downforce on the horizontal stabiliser, and therefore means that the main wing is lifting a heavier load. This leads to increased drag (sometimes called trim drag), increased stall speed, lower maximum altitude, etc. This is opposed to an aft CG, which reduces all those negative effects, for the trade-off of reduced stability. This makes it useful for us to be able to change the CG of the aircraft so we do not have to contend with as much trim drag. To do this, a trim fuel tank can be fitted in the rear of the aircraft, which is usually transferred and then burnt at the correct time to ensure peak efficiency, with the best possible CG position. This is the reason they are fitted in the tail of the aircraft, as that is the place furthest away from the CG, to have the greatest effect. An interesting side note, Concorde had such trim tanks in the tail of the aircraft, and fuel would be pumped to them to bring the CG backwards when accelerating through the transonic range, in order to counteract the effects of Mach tuck. This drastically reduced the drag of a conventional Mach trim system, and the reverse would occur when the aircraft decelerated back to subsonic flight again.

The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings. Aircraft with integral fuel tanks in the wings are said to have wet wings. RIGID TANKS: A rigid tank is a sealed metal container strapped into a compartment designed to accomodate the tank in the airframe structure. They are simple and may be removed for inspection, replacement, or repair. However, this type of tank adds extra weight. FLEXIBLE TANKS/FUEL BLADDERS: Flexible tanks are reinforced rubberized bags installed in a section of the aircraft structure designed to accommodate the weight of the fuel. A bladder tank contains most of the features and components of a rigid tank but does not require as large an opening in the aircraft skin to install. It is rolled up and installed into the compartment through the fuel filler neck or access panel, and is secured by means of metal buttons or snaps inside the compartment. content.question: What can happen if both the LP booster pumps in a fuel tank fail?

options.A: Fuel starvation due to lack of pressure for fuel transfer.
options.B: Restriction of speed due to limited fuel flow.
options.C: Cavitation at low altitude.
options.D: Cavitation at high altitude.

key_points: In a large aircraft fuel system, there are usually 2 stages of fuel pumps
Just before the engines are the high pressure (HP) pumps which provide the correct pressure to the fuel nozzles

The suction from these pumps can suck fuel straight out of the tanks, through the fuel lines, however, this is usually supplemented by the addition of low pressure (LP) fuel pumps to suck fuel out of the tank and push it into the fuel lines
learning.explanation: In a large aircraft fuel system, there are usually 2 stages of fuel pumps. Just before the engines are the high pressure (HP) pumps which provide the correct pressure to the fuel nozzles. The suction from these pumps can suck fuel straight out of the tanks, through the fuel lines, however, this is usually supplemented by the addition of low pressure (LP) fuel pumps to suck fuel out of the tank and push it into the fuel lines. This pressurises the fuel in the lines, preventing vapour lock and cavitation. Cavitation is where an object moves through a liquid too quickly, and "tears" the liquid, creating gas bubbles in the liquid, even when no gas is present. This can reduce the output pressure of the pumps and therefore reduce fuel flow to the engines. It is much harder to do when the liquid is under pressure, so is more likely at high altitude when the air pressure is not pushing down on the liquid as much inside the fuel tanks. As discussed above, cavitation is reduced by pressurising the fuel, in smaller aircraft by using ram air to push down on the fuel in the tank, and in larger aircraft with LP pumps to pressurise the fuel lines. The failure of LP pumps does not stop the engines from receiving fuel, but cavitation and vapour lock (gas bubbles in the fuel lines) can cause fuel interruptions to the engine.

learning.explanation: FUEL SYSTEM The fuel system in the aircraft that you fly has several purposes, including storing fuel and delivering a steady flow of fuel from the tanks to the engine at adequate pressure and temperature (regardless of power settings, the aircraft’s altitude, or attitude) ensuring engine operation. Another function of the fuel system is to ensure fuel balance (even fuel distribution), via a crossfeed system, resulting in optimization of centre of gravity position. FUEL SYSTEM CS 25.951 General (a) Each fuel system must be constructed and arranged to ensure a flow of fuel at a rate and pressure established for proper engine functioning under each likely operating condition, including any manoeuvre for which certification is requested and during which the engine is permitted to be in operation. (b) Each fuel system must be arranged so that any air which is introduced into the system will not result in – (1) Reserved. (2) Flameout. (c) Each fuel system must be capable of sustained operation throughout its flow and pressure range with fuel initially saturated with water at 26.7°C (80°F) and having 0.20 cm3 of free water per litre (0.75 cm3 per US gallon) added and cooled to the most critical condition for icing likely to be encountered in operation. To go through each option: "To automatically shut down the fuel supply if an engine malfunction occurs." Certainly not. "To ensure that 100% of the fuel flow required in the most critical phase of flight is provided." Correct. This is the most important task of the fuel system, to ensure that adequate fuel flow to the engines is provided, in the worst possible expected conditions and any manoeuvre, etc. as mentioned above. "To provide continuous flow of fuel under each expected operating condition, ensuring it is not interrupted for more than 3 seconds." It starts well, but then is made incorrect by the "3 seconds". The fuel system must be able to provide continuous and adequate fuel flow in all expected operating conditions at all times. "To detect any water in the system and remove it." No, it must be capable of operation with some water in the fuel, as stated in the CS-25 regulation above.

Whenever there is an unexpected fuel quantity indication, a message related to fuel in the FMC or engine display, or an imbalance condition arises, it's essential to consider the possibility of a fuel leak. Detecting a fuel leak can be aided by maintaining a fuel log and comparing the actual fuel burn to the planned fuel burn as part of the flight. It's important to note that there is no specific onboard warning for a fuel leak; it must be identified through changes or discrepancies in expected fuel consumption. Before engaging in any crossfeeding operations, it's crucial to ascertain that a fuel leak is not the root cause of the issue, as it could lead to total fuel loss. Pay close attention to parameters such as fuel flow, fuel usage, and total fuel quantity indications before deactivating any pump switches. If there is suspicion of an inflight fuel leak, take the following steps: turn off the fuel pumps for the center wing tank and close the crossfeed valve. Monitor the fuel tank quantity for any unusual drops and be alert to signs of a fuel imbalance, as these indicators can help confirm the presence of an engine fuel leak. Once an engine fuel leak is confirmed, either through visual observation or flight deck indications, it's imperative to shut down the affected engine to halt the leak and preserve the remaining fuel. After shutting down the affected engine, resume normal fuel management procedures. All remaining fuel can be utilized to power the operational engine safely.

learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The capacitance-type fuel gauging system measures the volume of fuel by measuring the capacitance of the tank which depends on the proportion of dielectrics (fuel and air) within the tanks. Which one of the following statements is true when checking and using fuses and circuit breakers?

(2) Circuit breakers should never be reset
(3) Circuit breakers should not be reset too often
(4) After a fuse has tripped, it is better to replace it with a fuse of a higher rating
(5) After a fuse has tripped, it is better to replace it with a fuse of a lower rating

key_points: CIRCUIT BREAKERS: They combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit

Circuit breakers are special because even after the circuit breaker has blown, the circuit can be closed again
learning.explanation: CIRCUIT BREAKERS: They combine the function of a fuse and a switch in one unit. As well as providing protection to the circuit, they can be used to switch a circuit on and off in certain circumstances. Circuit breakers are special because even after the circuit breaker has blown, the circuit can be closed again. Therefore restoring the circuit and potentially powering important systems. Hence a circuit breaker is resettable. However, a Circuit Breaker should not be reset too often - If a circuit breaker trips, it means there is more current flowing through that circuit breaker than its trip current - if you keep resetting a circuit breaker, you basically keep allowing the overcurrent to flow, which could potentially damage systems. => Therefore, statement (3) is correct. FUSES: are a sacrificial device that is destroyed and needs to be replaced or rewired to be functional again when tripped. Therefore they are not resettable. When it’s time to replace the fuse, it’s important to find one that has the same amperage and voltage rating. => Therefore, statement (6) is correct.

content.question: In a DC (Direct Current) circuit, what will happen if the current gets too high and is not detected?

options.A: The voltage will subsequently increase, and could blow a fuse.
options.B: The wire will overheat and could cause a fire.
options.C: The increased magnetic field will interfere with other circuits nearby.
options.D: The circuit breaker will trip, disconnecting the generator from its drive unit.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.07.06: Explain the risk of fire resulting from excessive heat in a circuit subjected to overcurrent. Circuit overload protections exist for very good reason. If an electrical consumer ever attempts to pull more current that it should be allowed to have, then that should be stopped, by the blowing of a fuse (which has to then be changed) or the popping of a circuit breaker. This serves many reasons. If a consumer tries to pull much more power than usual, then it may be that the consumer has broken somehow, or a short-circuit has occurred somewhere, which is allowing all the electricity an easy path to ground. This will allow a high level of current through that circuit, which could heat up rapidly, and most circuits are not built for that level of heat or current, so could easily start an electrical fire. This may also remove so much of the available current in the system as well, potentially starving the other consumers of power. In this case, the circuit protection has not worked, so the circuit can overcurrent. This is why we have circuit breakers and fuses, so that if too much current passes through our circuit, the fuse would melt, breaking the connection, or, in a circuit breaker, the excess current would cause a solenoid to pop out the breaker, breaking the connection. Circuit breakers may be reset once (after a few seconds to let the circuit cool), but if they pop again, there is a problem with the circuit and they should not be reset again. There are "slow blow" fuses and circuit breakers, which take a few seconds of overcurrent to break the connection, for those circuits which are allowed to go over a certain current for a transient time only. Note: This is a very similar question to Q216001, but with different options.

learning.explanation: In the diagram you can see the most basic type of thermal circuit breaker. Thermal circuit breakers consist of two different types of metals, that are specifically chosen for their expansion rates for a certain temperature. Usually the top metal (shown in red) is copper, and the bottom metal (shown in blue) is iron. As the current exceeds a set maximum, the metals will start to expand due to the excess heat. Now, because of the different expansion rates of the materials, the metal strip will bend and disconnect from the circuit, hence preventing anymore current from flowing. Why is the correct answer “protects the system in the event of a prolonged overcurrent”: The overcurrent needs to be prolonged so that the materials have time to heat up and start expanding. Usually when an overcurrent occurs, the current is so much higher than the maximum current that it takes very little time (under a second) for the circuit breaker to trip. However, low over-currents can take minutes to cause the breaker to trip. The correct answer needs to contain overcurrent because thermal circuit breakers “protect” from overcurrent, they are not designed to trip at a specific surrounding air temperature. Even if a high temperature could trip the circuit breakers!

options.B: they produce heat, so firefighters have to be present during loading and unloading.
options.C: they freeze, causing their metal case to crack.
options.D: they are prone to thermal runaway if they overheat.

key_points: Note: This question was made from incomplete feedback, so could be different from what you see in the exam
Any further exam feedback can be put in the comments or sent to info@atplquestions
com Learning Obective 021
learning.explanation: Note: This question was made from incomplete feedback, so could be different from what you see in the exam. Any further exam feedback can be put in the comments or sent to info@atplquestions.com Learning Obective 021.09.02.01.09: Explain how lithium-type batteries pose a threat to aircraft safety and what affects this risk: numbers of batteries on board an aircraft including those brought on board by passengers; temperature, of both battery and environment; physical condition of the battery; battery charging. There are a few different types of lithium batteries, Lithium ion, Lithium metal and lithium polymer. They all have slightly different characteristics, but share a similar level of danger. They are all susceptible to thermal runaway. This can come about in a few different ways, depending on the battery type. Lithium ion batteries, for instance, are most susceptible to thermal runaway through overcharging/overheating and damage, which can stop the battery controller from working correctly. Some of the batteries are also very susceptible to swelling with age and internal pressure, and internal short circuits can also cause thermal runaway. This makes lithium batteries dangerous goods, and the vast majority of them are "forbidden" on aircraft, except for certain amounts in hand luggage and as crew spares, which can be monitored and dealt with in case of a fire. This is important because a lithium fire burns incredibly hot and is almost impossible to put out without specialist equipment. This does mean that the scenario in this question is highly unlikely to occur, but as they are dangerous goods, the crew must be notified via a NOTOC, and of the options given, only the one stating thermal runaway is correct (Although some of the options are not verified so will likely be different in the exam).

content.question: If an electrical circuit overload occurs but is NOT detected, what might occur?

options.A: The fuse may blow.
options.B: The generators will overheat and fail.
options.C: The bypass line will be activated.
options.D: The electrical line could overheat and cause a fire.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.07.06: Explain the risk of fire resulting from excessive heat in a circuit subjected to overcurrent. Circuit overload protections exist for very good reason. If an electrical consumer ever attempts to pull more current that it should be allowed to have, then that should be stopped, by the blowing of a fuse (which has to then be changed) or the popping of a circuit breaker. This serves many reasons. If a consumer tries to pull much more power than usual, then it may be that the consumer has broken somehow, or a short-circuit has occurred somewhere, which is allowing all the electricity an easy path to ground. This will allow a high level of current through that circuit, which could heat up rapidly, and most circuits are not built for that level of heat or current, so could easily start an electrical fire. This may also remove so much of the available current in the system as well, potentially starving the other consumers of power. In this case, the circuit protection has not worked, so the circuit can overcurrent. This is why we have circuit breakers and fuses, so that if too much current passes through our circuit, the fuse would melt, breaking the connection, or, in a circuit breaker, the excess current would cause a solenoid to pop out the breaker, breaking the connection. Circuit breakers may be reset once (after a few seconds to let the circuit cool), but if they pop again, there is a problem with the circuit and they should not be reset again. There are "slow blow" fuses and circuit breakers, which take a few seconds of overcurrent to break the connection, for those circuits which are allowed to go over a certain current for a transient time only.

content.question: A pilot sees a very high oil temperature indication on IDG 1 and follows the associated abnormal checklist, which results in them disconnecting IDG 1 from the engine. Which of the following is correct, after disconnecting the IDG?

options.A: The generator will stop providing electricity, and can only be reconnected on the ground.
options.B: IDG 1 will continue to provide electricity even when disconnected from the AC bus bar.
options.C: IDG 1 will continue to provide electricity even when mechanically disconnected from the AC bus bar, but cannot be re-connected in flight.
options.D: The IDG will stop providing electricity, but can be re-connected in flight after a sufficient cooling period.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.03.03.04: Explain the consequences of a mechanical disconnection during flight for a CSD and an IDG. An integrated drive generator (IDG) consists of a Constant Speed Drive (CSD) unit and an electrical generator which are located inside one casing. As an IDG is a self contained system, the fault light in the cockpit can tell us of any problems, and sometimes there is a temperature dial that can tell us of an overheat in the lubricating oil, etc., which might require the IDG to be disconnected from the engine gearbox. If a pilot has to manually disconnect the IDG, they must operate the IDG disconnect switch. The IDG switch is guarded and normally spring loaded out. When operated, the IDG is disconnected from its drive shaft (mechanically breaks the link between the IDG and the engine gearbox) and can only be reconnected by maintenance, after engine shutdown. Many IDGs are able to automatically disconnect when a high oil temperature occurs, and therefore require no input from the pilot on this issue, but this will have the same effect as manually disconnecting the IDG, which means that the in-built generator will be unusable for the rest of the flight, and can only be re-connected on the ground by engineers, so that electrical supply is unavailable for the remainder of the flight.

content.question: In order to produce an alternating voltage of 400 Hz, the RPM required for a 6-pole AC generator is…

key_points: The formula used for these questions: AC GEN output frequency (Hz) = (Rotor RPM) x (N° pole pairs) ÷ 60 The output frequency is given as 400 hz and the number of poles is 6 (3 pole pairs), filling in the blanks: Warning! Do not confuse the pole pairs with the number of poles! AC GEN output frequency (hz) = (Rotor RPM) x (N° pole pairs) ÷ 60 400 = [(Rotor RPM) x (3)] / 60 Rotor RPM = 24 000 / 3 Rotor RPM = 8000 RPM

content.question: A Captain and an engineer are performing a walk-around together when they discover a 3 amp blown fuse. The engineer only has 5 amp fuses left to use, and the Captain gives them permission to fit this fuse instead. Is this acceptable?

options.A: This is acceptable and no problems will occur.
options.B: This is not acceptable, the circuit will not function at all.
options.C: The circuit will catch fire.
options.D: This may be acceptable for a period, however, overcurrents will go undetected for a period of time.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.09.01.07.08: Explain the hazards of multiple resets of a circuit breaker or the use of incorrect fuse rating when replacing blown fuses. A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical current when failures occur. Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accommodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects. If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit. Any failures (such as short circuits) could cause a failure of the circuit and its components, which may even heat up enough to start a fire. The fuse is designed as a safety device. It should not only be the correct amperage but also the correct voltage and fast or slow blow. In other words, if an over-current is allowed - by fitting an incorrect fuse rating, for example - there is a risk of an electrical fire. However, it is important to note that, in a healthy circuit, nothing will happen as long as the circuit does not encounter an overload condition. In this case, a small overload of 4 amps, for instance, would not be protected against, and there is an increased risk of electrical fire. As for the other options: It is not completely safe to do. It will not cause the circuit to stop working. A fire will not immediately start, but is just more likely, in case of failure of other components.

options.B: To avoid leaking of its liquid coolant.

Housing lithium-ion batteries in a vented metal casing can help to prevent them from becoming a fire hazard by reducing the risk of thermal runaway, which is a condition in which the battery temperature increases rapidly, potentially leading to ignition
learning.explanation: Note: We have limited feedback about this question and it may be different in the exam. Please send us any further exam feedback in the comments, by email to info@atplquestions.com or in the exam feedback section of your dashboard, thanks! Housing lithium-ion batteries in a vented metal casing can help to prevent them from becoming a fire hazard by reducing the risk of thermal runaway, which is a condition in which the battery temperature increases rapidly, potentially leading to ignition. The vented casing allows for dissipation of heat and venting of any flammable gases that may be generated during thermal runaway. The other options listed are not effective in preventing lithium-ion batteries from becoming a fire hazard. Installing a fuse on the positive pole of the battery does not address the root cause of thermal runaway, and may not provide adequate protection against ignition. Placing a halon fire extinguisher in the compartment with the battery is not a proactive measure to prevent thermal runaway and may not be able to effectively extinguish a fire that has already started. Continuously charging the battery during flight also does not prevent thermal runaway, and may actually increase the risk of thermal runaway if the battery is overcharged or damaged in some way.

content.question: In a large twin-engine jet transport aircraft, on the ground with the engines shut down, a ground power unit (GPU) is feeding power to AC BUS 2, thus powering the electrical components on the circuit primarily for the right hand side of the aircraft. How can the pilot power the components connected to the left hand circuit?

options.A: It is not possible to power both with one source.
options.B: Disconnect the GPU from AC BUS 2 and connect it to AC BUS 1.
options.C: It is either done automatically or manually from the flight deck.
options.D: Use the aircraft battery to power the left hand circuit components.

key_points: Any large aircraft electrical distribution system (parallel or split bus, though split bus is most likely for this case) can be fed completely from a ground power unit (GPU)

The GPU feeds AC power to the aircraft, the same as engine or APU driven generators, and when accepted by the aircraft (usually by pilot control), the GPU will feed the AC transfer busses or AC main busses on both sides, as there is no need to keep the busses isolated from each other when they are both fed from the same source (APU or GPU)

If the GPU were only feeding AC BUS 2 for whatever reason, then the system would either automatically revert to feeding both AC transfer/main busses (perhaps if the APU was switched off whilst feeding AC BUS 1), or in some cases, the pilot may have to choose to feed both busses from the GPU
learning.explanation: Any large aircraft electrical distribution system (parallel or split bus, though split bus is most likely for this case) can be fed completely from a ground power unit (GPU). The GPU feeds AC power to the aircraft, the same as engine or APU driven generators, and when accepted by the aircraft (usually by pilot control), the GPU will feed the AC transfer busses or AC main busses on both sides, as there is no need to keep the busses isolated from each other when they are both fed from the same source (APU or GPU). If the GPU were only feeding AC BUS 2 for whatever reason, then the system would either automatically revert to feeding both AC transfer/main busses (perhaps if the APU was switched off whilst feeding AC BUS 1), or in some cases, the pilot may have to choose to feed both busses from the GPU.

content.question: Given a wire fed with alternating current and a second wire parallel to, but remote from it. The result will be…

options.A: The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and direct current will be induced in the second wire.
options.B: The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and the second wire will double the transmission power of the first one.
options.C: The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space and alternating current will be induced in the second wire.
options.D: The first wire will radiate electro-magnetic waves into space but the transmitted energy will be completely absorbed by the second wire.

key_points: A quick translation of this question, there are 2 wires near each other, parallel but not connected together or touching
An alternating current (AC) is passed through one of the wires, what will happen in the other wire
This is a question about magnetic fields and the motor effect
learning.explanation: A quick translation of this question, there are 2 wires near each other, parallel but not connected together or touching. An alternating current (AC) is passed through one of the wires, what will happen in the other wire. This is a question about magnetic fields and the motor effect. When a current is passed through a wire, it creates a circular magnetic field going around that wire, which affects any free electrons in the vicinity, movement of electrons (current) is directly linked to magnetic fields. The other wire nearby will feel this magnetic field and electrons will begin to move because of it, creating a current. It is not the physical presence of the magnetic field which causes the EMF (electromotive force) that creates the current though, it is the change in magnetic field. There are magnetic fields present all around us (notable that of the Earth which makes our compasses work), but these do not create electricity, unless they change. The question mentions an alternating current, which means that the current goes forwards and backwards in the wire, changing a few times per second (50 times per second is normal for mains power supply - depending on the country), this means that the magnetic field around the first wire is continuously created and destroyed, then created and destroyed in the opposite direction, then back to the first direction, etc. This creates a similar backwards, forwards, backwards, forwards current in the second wire, which is again called alternating current (AC)! This effect can be used to create movement in motors (by creating opposing magnetic fields) and to generate/transfer electricity, but remember, energy cannot come from nowhere, so there must be an opposite effect (called back EMF) somewhere in the system. Note: This came from feedback in RNAV a while ago, but it is certainly an AGK-electrics question, so any feedback about whether this question is still active, etc. would be very useful, thank you.

content.question: A constant speed drive (CSD) that has been disconnected in flight…

options.A: can be reset only on the ground after engine shut-down.
options.B: can be reset in flight using the reset mechanism.
options.C: automatically resets in flight providing engine rpm is below a given value.
options.D: automatically resets on engine shut-down.

key_points: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU or CSD
The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred as speed
In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current
learning.explanation: An AC generator driven by a constant speed unit is also known as a Constant Speed Generator Drive System, CSDU or CSD. The main function of this system is to maintain a constant frequency, sometimes referred as speed. In other words, it is a hydromechanical unit that turns the physical motion of oil/fluid into an AC or DC current. The output of the hydraulic motor, and therefore the speed of the motor is dictated by the angle of the swash plate. The angle of the swash plate will either limit or increase the oil flow towards the hydraulic and in turn affect the rpm of the engine. The angle of the swash plate is controlled by the speed governor, which in turned is controlled by the load controller. The load controller senses the output frequency of the alternator and will adjust the swash plate accordingly to increase or decrease the torque output to the generator. The CSD can be disconnected from the engine drive shaft at any time during flight. However, only the engineers can reconnect the CSD, on the ground, with the engines off.

content.question: When using a fuse with a higher rating than prescribed…

options.A: The current in the circuit will be too high, resulting in a blown fuse.
options.B: The whole circuit will overheat, which is a potential fire hazard.
options.C: In a healthy system nothing problematic will happen.
options.D: It will take too much time to detect an open circuit.

key_points: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur

Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects
If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit
learning.explanation: A fuse is a thermal circuit protection device which protects distribution system cables and components against excessive electrical currect when failures occur. Fuses are rated to a specific maximum current specified in amperes and will rupture (meaning that the fusible will melt and open the circuit) at a slightly higher value to accomodate surge as a load is switched on and is in series with the load it protects. If you replace a fuse with a higher amp one it will work but create an unsafe circuit. It could cause a failure of the device burn it up, start a fire. The fuse is designed as a safety device. If the circuit does encounter an overload condition then that part of the circuit that the fuse protects may become a fire hazard.
